sen.j: 三上藩（みかみはん）は、滋賀県野洲市野洲町三上に存在した藩。
sen.e: Mikami Domain was in Mikami, Yasu-cho, Yasu City, Shiga Prefecture.
The Mikami Domain was in Mikami, Yasu-cho, Yasu City, Shiga Prefecture.
The Mikami Domain was in Mikami, Yasu-cho, Yasu City, Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 藩庁は三上陣屋（城主大名）。
sen.e: Government building of domain was in Mikami jinya (regional government office) (governors of castles).
The government building of the domain was in Mikami jinya (regional government office) (governors of castles).
sen.cmt: 文頭にTheを追加し、domain→the domainに修正しました。
sen.e: The government building of the domain was in Mikami jinya (regional government office) (governors of castles).

sen.j: 藩主家は遠藤氏である。
sen.e: The family of lord of the domain was Endo clan.
The family of lord of the domain was the Endo clan.
The family of lord of the domain was the Endo clan.

sen.j: 遠藤氏は美濃国郡上藩を領していたが、遠藤常久が7歳の時に家臣によって毒殺され、さらに先代から続いていた家督騒動が家臣団の内部で再燃したため、幕命により常久に嗣子が無かったために改易に処された。
sen.e: Endo clan ruled over Gujo Domain of the Mino Province, and Tsunehisa Endo was poisoned to death by his vassal at 7 years old, in addition to the recurrence of trouble concerning reigns of the family among vassals; therefore, Endo clan had its properties confiscated by the bakufu since Tsunehisa did not have an heir.

The Endo clan ruled over the Gujo Domain of the Mino Province, and Tsunehisa ENDO was poisoned to death by his vassal at seven years old, in addition to the recurrence of trouble concerning reigns of the family among vassals; therefore, the Endo clan had its properties confiscated by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) since Tsunehisa did not have an heir.
sen.cmt: The Endo clan, the Gujo Domainとし、Tsunehisa Endo→Tsunehisa ENDOに修正、7をスペルアウト、bakufuの補足を追加しました。
sen.e: The Endo clan ruled over the Gujo Domain of the Mino Province, and Tsunehisa ENDO was poisoned to death by his vassal at seven years old, in addition to the recurrence of trouble concerning reigns of the family among vassals; therefore, the Endo clan had its properties confiscated by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) since Tsunehisa did not have an heir.

sen.j: しかし、藩祖である遠藤慶隆の功績を賞されて、元禄5年（1692年）に遠藤胤親が常陸国・下野国で1万石を与えられて、遠藤氏の再興が認められたのである。
sen.e: However, in 1692 in praise of the achievements by Yoshitaka Endo the original forefather of the domain, Tanechika Endo was granted 10,000 koku crop yields in Hitachi Province and Shimotsuke Province; thus, the restoration of Endo clan was accepted.

However, in 1692 in praise of the achievements by Yoshitaka ENDO the original forefather of the domain, Tanechika ENDO was granted 10,000 koku crop yields in Hitachi Province and Shimotsuke Province; thus, the restoration of the Endo clan was accepted.
sen.cmt: Yoshitaka Endo→Yoshitaka ENDO、Tanechika Endo→Tanechika ENDOに修正、the Endo clanとしました。
sen.e: However, in 1692 in praise of the achievements by Yoshitaka ENDO the original forefather of the domain, Tanechika ENDO was granted 10,000 koku crop yields in Hitachi Province and Shimotsuke Province; thus, the restoration of the Endo clan was accepted.

sen.j: 元禄11年（1698年）3月7日、胤親は所領を近江国四郡に移されて、ここに三上藩が立藩したのである。
sen.e: In 1698 Tanechika was transferred in his territory to four counties of Omi Province, resulting in the establishment of Mikami Domain.
On April 17, 1698, Tanechika was transferred in his territory to four counties of Omi Province, resulting in the establishment of the Mikami Domain.
sen.cmt: 「3月7日」→訳漏れのため訳出 (新暦に修正)、the Mikami Domainとしました。
sen.e: On April 17, 1698, Tanechika was transferred in his territory to four counties of Omi Province, resulting in the establishment of the Mikami Domain.

sen.j: 第5代藩主・遠藤胤統（若年寄）の代である嘉永5年（1852年）12月25日、江戸城西の丸造営の功績を賞されて、2,000石の加増を受けた。
sen.e: In 1852 the fifth lord of the domain Tanenori Endo (wakadoshiyori) received additional 2,000 koku crop yields in appreciation of his achievement in constructing a castle compound to the west of the main compound of Edo-jo Castle.

On February 3, 1853, the fifth lord of the domain Tanenori ENDO (wakadoshiyori) received additional 2,000 koku crop yields in appreciation of his achievement in constructing a castle compound to the west of the main compound of Edo-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 「12月25日」→訳漏れのため訳出(新暦に修正)、Tanenori Endo→Tanenori ENDOに修正mしました。
sen.e: On February 3, 1853, the fifth lord of the domain Tanenori ENDO (wakadoshiyori) received additional 2,000 koku crop yields in appreciation of his achievement in constructing a castle compound to the west of the main compound of Edo-jo Castle.

sen.j: 幕末期の万延元年（1860年）4月15日には城主格に任じられた。
sen.e: In the end of Edo period of 1860 he held the status of daimyo who was allowed to live in a castle.
On June 4, 1860 in the end of the Edo period, he held the status of daimyo (feudal lord) who was allowed to live in a castle.
sen.cmt: the Edo periodとし、daimyoの補足追加、「4月15日」→訳漏れのため訳出、一部訳文を修正しました。(新暦に修正)
sen.e: On June 4, 1860 in the end of the Edo period, he held the status of daimyo (feudal lord) who was allowed to live in a castle.

sen.j: 文久3年（1863年）10月7日に胤統は隠居し、後を孫の遠藤胤城が継いだ。
sen.e: In 1863 Tanenori retired, and his grandson Taneki Endo succeeded him.
On November 17, 1863, Tanenori retired, and his grandson Taneki ENDO succeeded him.
sen.cmt: 「10月7日」→訳漏れのため訳出 (新暦に修正)、Taneki Endo→Taneki ENDOに修正しました。
sen.e: On November 17, 1863, Tanenori retired, and his grandson Taneki ENDO succeeded him.

sen.j: 胤城は講武所奉行に任じられ、長州征伐などに活躍した。
sen.e: Taneki took office as a magistrate of Kobusho, and he played an active part in the Choshu Expeditions.
Taneki took office as a magistrate of Kobusho (military training institute), and he played an active part in the Choshu Expeditions.
sen.cmt: Kobushoの補足を追加しました。(用語集参照)
sen.e: Taneki took office as a magistrate of Kobusho (military training institute), and he played an active part in the Choshu Expeditions.

sen.j: 将軍・徳川慶喜の代には奏者番に任じられて将軍側近となり、佐幕派としての立場を貫いた。
sen.e: Under the rule of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA Taneki, appointed as soshaban (officer telling shogun about daimyo who came for greetings), became a close adviser of shogun, and he held onto his standpoint as Sabaku-ha (supporters of the Shogun).

Under the rule of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA Taneki, appointed as soshaban (officer telling shogun about daimyo who came for greetings), became a close adviser of shogun, and he held onto his standpoint as Sabaku-ha (supporters of the shogun).

Under the rule of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA Taneki, appointed as soshaban (officer telling shogun about daimyo who came for greetings), became a close adviser of shogun, and he held onto his standpoint as Sabaku-ha (supporters of the shogun).

sen.j: しかしこのため、慶応4年（1868年）1月に新政府から敵と見なされて領地を召し上げられた。
sen.e: However, due to this he was regarded as an enemy by the new government, and he had his territory confiscated in 1868.
However, due to this he was regarded as an enemy by the new government, and he had his territory confiscated in January 1868.
sen.cmt: 「1月」→訳漏れのため訳出しました。
sen.e: However, due to this he was regarded as an enemy by the new government, and he had his territory confiscated in January 1868.

sen.j: 同年5月29日、罪を許されて領地は戻され、翌年6月23日には三上藩知事に任じられた。
sen.e: In the same year Taneki was released from the punishment to recover his territory, and in the following year he assumed office as governor of Mikami Domain.
On July 18 in the same year Taneki was released from the punishment to recover his territory, and on July 31 in the following year he assumed office as governor of the Mikami Domain.
sen.cmt: 「5月29日」「6月23日」→訳漏れのため訳出(新暦に修正)、the Mikami Domainとしました。
sen.e: On July 18 in the same year Taneki was released from the punishment to recover his territory, and on July 31 in the following year he assumed office as governor of the Mikami Domain.

sen.j: その後、胤城は明治3年（1870年）4月14日、藩庁を和泉国吉見に移したため、以後は吉見藩として存続することとなったのである。
sen.e: Subsequently because Taneki transferred government building of domain to Yoshimi of Izumi Province in 1870, Mikami Domain continued to exist as Yoshimi Domain afterwards.
Subsequently because Taneki transferred the government building of the domain to Yoshimi of Izumi Province on May 14, 1870, the Mikami Domain continued to exist as the Yoshimi Domain afterwards.
sen.cmt: 「4月14日」→訳漏れのため訳出(新暦に修正)、the government building of the domain、the Mikami Domain、the Yoshimi Domainとしました。
sen.e: Subsequently because Taneki transferred the government building of the domain to Yoshimi of Izumi Province on May 14, 1870, the Mikami Domain continued to exist as the Yoshimi Domain afterwards.

sen.j: 伝裏門・・三上の集落内の個人宅に移築
sen.e: Back gate was dismantled and reconstructed in an individual residence in a village of Mikami.
Back gate (according to legend) was dismantled and reconstructed in an individual residence in a village of Mikami.
Back gate (according to legend) was dismantled and reconstructed in an individual residence in a village of Mikami.

sen.j: 永原御殿・・草津市の芦浦観音寺書院に移築されている。（重要文化財）
sen.e: Nagahara Goten (palace) was dismantled and reconstructed in shoin of Ashiura Kannon-ji Temple in Kusatsu City. (important cultural heritage)
Nagahara Goten (palace) was dismantled and reconstructed in shoin (reception room) of Ashiura Kannon-ji Temple in Kusatsu City (important cultural heritage).
sen.cmt: shoinの補足を追加しました。(用語集参照)
sen.e: Nagahara Goten (palace) was dismantled and reconstructed in shoin (reception room) of Ashiura Kannon-ji Temple in Kusatsu City (important cultural heritage).

sen.j: 貞亨（1686）年幕府の命により廃城。
sen.e: In 1686 the palace fell into disuse by the order of bakufu.
In 1686 the palace fell into disuse by the order of the bakufu.
In 1686 the palace fell into disuse by the order of the bakufu.

sen.j: 将軍上洛御殿の一つ。
sen.e: One of the palaces used by the shogun going to Kyoto.
One of the palaces used by the shogun going to Kyoto.
One of the palaces used by the shogun going to Kyoto.

sen.j: この他、近江に柏原御殿・伊庭御殿・水口城御殿がある。
sen.e: Other palaces includes Kashiwabara Goten, Iba Goten and Minakuchi-jo Castle Goten in Omi region.
Other palaces includes Kashiwabara Goten, Iba Goten and Minakuchi-jo Castle Goten in Omi region.
Other palaces includes Kashiwabara Goten, Iba Goten and Minakuchi-jo Castle Goten in Omi region.

sen.j: 伝門・・野洲市の浄専寺に移築されてる。
sen.e: Gate was dismantled and reconstructed in Josen-ji Temple in Yasu City.
Gate (according to legend) was dismantled and reconstructed in Josen-ji Temple in Yasu City.
Gate (according to legend) was dismantled and reconstructed in Josen-ji Temple in Yasu City.
